ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have tried different new materials for art, which widens my skill set and inspires me to explore different medias.
I learned concepts of light/shadow, composition, and experimenting with collage

I enjoyed experimenting with different mediums, some that I had never really done before like large clay sculpture. It's a good class to try a couple of different art types, but I mainly took it because I had to for CPAR. I was a bit intimidated by the course at first, but then I realized you have a lot of freedom with what you make.
Physical media (such as collage and clay), as well as digital media (Adobe Fresco, digital drawing).
color wheel, compositions
Design thinking, composition, form, critique.
I strengthen my skills to independently synthesize a project when given the time and materials. I also developed more confidence surrounding the quality of the work I produced.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very fun, and the projects are creative. I think it would be great if we had more freedom on choosing our own theme/subject of each assignment.

I ultimately learned a lot conceptually, but the course could be more organized. I would like if we had printed syllabi detailing the plan for each week, so students know what to expect and how to prepare.
I felt like overall it was a great survey of different art techniques and mediums and I loved having in class work time! Anahita also is really helpful in providing feedback.

Strengths:
Wonderful opportunity to develop introductory skills in a variety of different media. Many opportunities for artistic choice and freedom with direct support and feedback from instructor. Important instruction of introductory principles of art, which were used to help ease students into the critique-structure of the Yale School of Art.

Weaknesses:
Highly disorganized and no clear syllabus. The course would have benefited greatly from a bit more structure and better communication about assignment deadlines.
Anahita is an amazing professor who really wants you to learn through experimentation and exploring your own interests.
Lots of personal time for projects and sweet feedback from teacher and classmates, but sometimes confusing course schedule.

A major weakness of the course is the lack of a serious environment. Often the art major is treated a supplementary course of study rather than a subject matter worth pursuing as a career. I found the lack of engagement of peers and the professor almost humorous at times. Visual Thinking would benefit from having a structured syllabus that overviews various techniques that students could then apply in their own practices. There also needs to be an understanding that critique is not just a time for praise. I often feel unable to express honest feedback because I am worried that I will hurt peoples feelings. However, when students put in little effort I don't see it as productive to pretend that the work it fantastic. Art is about iteration we need to support a culture in the classroom of constructive criticism and intentionality.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to students who are in art major, because this course explores techniques that people might never use, which is a very fun experience.
It's required for a valid reason
This is a cool course to take if you have no art experience and want to delve into some different techniques and mediums -- it's more of a survey course. Anahita is great too.

I would recommend this course to students who are considering the art major but are not certain which discipline they will concentrate in. The workload was extremely manageable and is great to add on as a fifth class. The course also provides a great opportunity for art students to refresh their foundational skills and vocabulary, which I deeply appreciated.
Yes!
Absolutely, especially if you're hoping to get the most out of your art major!
I would not recommend this course unless you are willing to take yourself seriously as an artists, receive criticism and put in the required hours.
